segments.text: Another one is a policeman himself.
He may be involved in some personal problems that would affect his performance on the job.
He might have a toothache.
He might have a bellyache.
Wife might have pussed at him.
He might not have got no sleep last night.
Maybe he's got a girlfriend about two weeks late.
he might have something of his mind.
To give you an example, there was an old boy that I started with.
And I made sergeant before he did.
Later on, he was made sergeant and given me to train.
We'd been friends from the time we met.
He developed a little gallbladder problem and went to the hospital to have a minor operation.
Doctor got in there.
Turns out it was terminal cancer.
He had less than 90 days to live.
I went by the hospital every day to see him.
Some days he was awake, some days he wasn't.
Some days we talked, some days we didn't.
Until he died.
The day he died was about 8, 3 in the morning.
Wack was there.
Her mother and dad were there.
He didn't have a mother and dad, he didn't know.
And, uh, got things pretty well settled down.
I got his wife in the car and took her home.
Then I got a call from one of the men that he needed a supervisor.
We get out there.

or I get out there and what he needed a supervisor for was that he had two grown men in a neighborhood there with new houses that had just been recently finished and they were arguing or the argument was over the location of a fence line in the back of the two houses
separated them out in between.
One of them said it was here, the other one said it was there, which was six inches difference.
The officer had explained to him that that was not a police problem, that was a civil problem, and that there wasn't anything he could do about it, and he'd talk to the other state people about it.
Survey people, title people, whatever.
And they were not satisfied with his decision and insisted that he call the supervisor.
I listened to all this, and I had this other problem on my mind.
I told them at the time that they had to explain what the problem was, and this officer explained to you what the answer to the problem is.
Now, you goddamn son of a bitch, I've been in the hospital for the last 90 days with a friend that died this morning of cancer, and you called me over here to ask me the same thing?
Yes, I went through with it, in language and in accents.
Shit, I've been criticized for it in what form?
As it was, there was no complaint made.
There was no investigation made of it.
A policeman can get involved, yeah.
And he can blow up a caseload.
He's supposed to, but they're imperfect.
You just saw my last question.
Do you think the police, I mean, that the public expects the police to be perfect or not?
Sure.
They've got the right to expect it.
But they're not gonna get it.
Never will.
It can't be done.
Just like you expect A&M to win every football game.
But we can't do it.
Or we expect the Dallas Cowboys to.
Every spring season we expect Detective Rogers to be playing in the World Series.
They ain't gonna make it.
We expect perfection out of every policeman.
You can't expect anything less.
But realistically, you're never going to get it.
Just like one of the, to give you a sense of what I mean, one of the schools that I went to, the subject was investigation of traffic accidents, how to determine what happened and who was at fault.
and what could have been done to correct it that wasn't done or something like this.
The school was put on by Northwestern University out of Illinois, out of Chicago, the top accident investigation school in the country.
In their teaching, they teach theoretically the perfect way to investigate an accident.
And one of them was telling me, one of the instructors there, he spent three weeks on one accident.
We've got officers out here working 10 and 12 accidents a day.
We don't have that kind of time.
But they've got to teach you the theoretically perfect way to do something.
Then you adapt it to your own situation.
But you've got the benefit of the training.
to do it that way.
You shortcut what's required.
The same with your policeman.
You expect perfection, but you're going to get shortcuts.
Same question.
1968, Rich Nixon ran for president, a law and order platform, a big deal in the United States.
law and order this and law and order that.
After he was elected, millions and millions of dollars went to local law enforcement.
His what?
Millions and millions of dollars went out to local law enforcement.
What was an effect here?
Did y'all get new gear?
Was there any noticeable effect of his campaign on increasing law and order?
How did the money go out?
It went directly to local departments.
If it's $50 for you and $100 for you, I never heard of it.
OK. Now, there were LEAAs and different groups of this type, or federal grants.
Numerous of those, and they involved paperwork and justification and youth programs and this kind of stuff.
But just to be handed some money, I never heard of that.
It might have been.
OK.

um another political question during the time in the police force there were seven presidents with any uh that's not directly tied at local law enforcement is any any one president sitting out of his administration being the most favorable to law enforcement i don't believe really
The president himself could affect law enforcement to an appreciable degree.
You've got your legislative houses that pass the law, the courts that rule on them, the laws that have been in existence for years, the Supreme Court.
which, with the effect of some of the decisions, creates new laws, there would be very little noticeable effect from the president or the local law enforcement, I believe.
I don't know that one's been better or worse.
I guess, lastly, is there anything you'd like to add to anything that's been said or anything I didn't mention you think?
Is it important?
No.
The courts right now are one of the biggest problem areas, I believe, of the judicial system to complete.
their way of handling cases, the way they're requiring cases to be handled, the decisions of the appeal courts, and some of the decisions of the Supreme Court.
Hopefully, somewhere along the line, this will change to the rights of society as opposed to the rights of the accused.
If you don't have anything else to add, I guess that wraps it up.
Okay.
I'll go get my coffee.
